articles.description: European Union leaders are appealing to U.S. President Donald Trump to defend their security interests at a key summit with his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin over the war in Ukraine. The Europeans are desperate to exert some influence over a meeting that they have been sidelined from. It's unclear whether whether even Ukraine will take part. Trump says he wants to see on Friday whether Putin is serious about ending the war. But he has disappointed U.S. allies by saying that Ukraine will have to give up some Russian-held territory. In a statement early Tuesday, the EU leaders welcomed his efforts to end the war, but insisted that “the path to peace in Ukraine cannot be decided without Ukraine.”
articles.title: EU leaders appeal to Trump to defend Europe's security interests at his war summit with Putin

articles.description: Washington, D.C., Mayor Muriel Bowser has responded to President Donald Trump's plan to take over the Metropolitan Police Department and call in the National Guard. Bowser emphasized that crime has been dropping and Trump's state of emergency doesn't match the numbers. She acknowledged that the city has little choice but to comply. Bowser linked the takeover to the larger issue of D.C. statehood, stating that limited autonomy makes the city vulnerable. Trump's decision fits a pattern of using emergency declarations to rule by executive order. Bowser maintains that violent crime has decreased, a claim supported by Trump's former U.S. attorney nominee.
articles.title: Washington, D.C., grapples with notion of Trump federal intervention

articles.description: Texas Republican leaders say they're prepared to end their stalemated legislative special session and immediately begin another standoff with Democrats in the GOP’s efforts to redraw congressional maps as directed by President Donald Trump. Texas House Speaker Dustin Burrows confirmed the plans Tuesday during a brief session that marked another failure to meet the required attendance standards. Dozens of Democrats have left the state and left the GOP majority unable to move forward with its gerrymandering attempt. Burrows said lawmakers will not reconvene again until Friday. If Democrats are still absent, Republican Gov. Greg Abbott said he will end the current session and will call another.
articles.title: Trump will get another session from Texas to redraw congressional maps

articles.description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth has expressed pride in being part of the Communion of Reformed Evangelical Churches, a conservative Christian network. Hegseth recently shared a CNN video about the church, showing its pastors arguing women should not have the right to vote. Hegseth is among President Donald Trump’s most controversial Cabinet picks and attends a CREC church in Tennessee. The church network has connections to Christian nationalism and practices complementarianism, emphasizing traditional gender roles. Network co-founder Pastor Doug Wilson leads the flagship Christ Church in Moscow, Idaho, and is known for his hard-line theology and patriarchal views. A Pentagon spokesman says Hegseth appreciates many of Wilson’s writings and teachings.
articles.title: Pentagon's Hegseth part of archconservative church network CREC

articles.description: The Israeli military says it recently struck a group of militants in the Gaza Strip who were disguised as aid workers and using a car with the logo of World Central Kitchen. That's an international charity founded by celebrity chef José Andrés. The army said it carried out an airstrike on the men after confirming with the charity that they were not affiliated with it and that the car did not belong to it. World Central Kitchen confirmed that the men and the vehicle were not affiliated with it and condemned anyone posing as humanitarians.
articles.title: Israel says it struck militants posing as aid workers in Gaza

articles.description: The Georgia Bureau of Investigation says the man who fired more than 180 shots at the headquarters of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound after killing a police officer. GBI Director Chris Hosey also said that documents found in a search of the suspect’s home “expressed the shooter’s discontent with the COVID-19 vaccinations.” Hosey said 30-year-old Patrick Joseph White also recently verbalized thoughts of suicide, which led to law enforcement being contacted several weeks before the shooting. He said White fatally shot DeKalb County Police Officer David Rose during the attack.
articles.title: CDC shooter died from a self-inflicted gunshot wound, Georgia investigators say

articles.description: Officials are still working to determine the cause of an explosion that rocked a steel plant outside Pittsburgh, leaving two dead and 10 injured. The blast occurred Monday at the Clairton plant in the Mon Valley. Emergency services say a fire started late morning, and a rescue effort continued into the night. The plant is still partially operational. Allegheny Health Network treated seven patients, discharging five. The rumbling from the explosion, and several smaller blasts that followed, was felt through the community about 15 miles southeast of Pittsburgh. U.S. Steel, now part of Nippon Steel, has promised a full investigation.
articles.title: Officials investigate what caused Pennsylvania steel plant explosion

articles.description: Records show the accused 32-year-old gunman who opened fire in a Target parking lot in Texas, killing two adults and a child, has a history of arrests for domestic violence and assault. Austin police identified the suspect as Ethan Nieneker, who investigators say fired on shoppers and then stole two cars during a getaway that ended with his arrest on the other side of the city. He was being held Tuesday on capital murder charges. Authorities have not offered a possible motive for Monday’s shooting. Austin Police Chief Lisa Davis said the suspect had “a mental health history” but did not elaborate.
articles.title: Suspect in shooting at Texas Target store had many run-ins with police

articles.description: U.S. inflation was unchanged in July as rising prices for some imported goods were balanced by falling gas and grocery prices, leaving overall prices modestly higher than a year ago. The figures suggest that slowing rent increases and cheaper gas are offsetting some impacts of President Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs. Many businesses are also absorbing much of the cost of the duties. Tuesday’s figures likely include some impact from the 10% universal tariff Trump imposed in April, as well as higher duties on countries such as China and Canada.
articles.title: US inflation held steady as mild tariff hit offset by cheaper gas, food

articles.description: Asian shares are mostly higher after President Donald Trump delayed raising tariffs on China for another 90 days. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 reached a new record high. Trump signed an executive order putting on hold a possible showdown between the world’s two major economies, to allow time for talks. Without an extension, taxes on Chinese imports might have jumped from an already high 30%. Beijing could have responded by raising retaliatory levies on U.S. exports to China but it issued a similar statement about the extension of the tariff pause. U.S. stocks edged back from record highs. The S&P 500 lost 0.3%, the Dow industrials fell 0.5% and the Nasdaq composite was down 0.3%.
articles.title: Asian shares advance on relief that Trump is delaying higher China tariffs
